Encoders¶

A listing of the encoders included in this library, specifically focused on the sklearn compatible transformers. For each one of these, an equivalent standalone method is also available.

Ordinal¶

class category_encoders.ordinal.OrdinalEncoder(verbose=0, mapping=None, cols=None)[source]¶

Ordinal encoding uses a single column of integers to represent the classes. An optional mapping dict can be passed in, in this case we use the knowledge that there is some true order to the classes themselves. Otherwise, the classes are assumed to have no true order and integers are selected at random.

Parameters:
  • verbose – foo
  • mapping – bar
  • cols – baz
Returns:
fit(X, y=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Fit doesn’t actually do anything in this case. So the same object is just returned as-is.

Parameters:
  • X –
  • y –
  • kwargs –
Returns:
transform(X)[source]¶

Will use the mapping (if available) and the column list (if available, otherwise every column) to encode the data ordinally.

Parameters:X –
Returns:

One-Hot¶

Scikit-learn already includes a one-hot encoder implementation, and we simply expose that as an option here. See their docs for detailed information.

Binary¶

class category_encoders.binary.BinaryEncoder(verbose=0, cols=None)[source]¶

Binary encoding encodes the integers as binary code with one column per digit.

  • cols –
